chapter.summary: Covers the management of cyclical breast pain in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 12 years onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage cyclical breast pain?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Reassure the woman that there is no serious underlying pathology. Offer written information on cyclical breast pain, such as the patient information on Breast pain provided by the NHS.
  • Consider the following treatment options:
    • A better-fitting bra during the day.
    • A soft support bra at night.
    • Oral paracetamol and/or ibuprofen, or a topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory preparation, as required. For more information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
  • Ask the woman to keep a pain diary (if she has not already done so) to evaluate the severity and timing of the pain, and its response to treatment. 
  • Consider referring to a breast specialist if the pain is severe enough to affect quality of life or sleep and does not respond to first-line treatment after 3 months. 
    • Specialist treatment options include danazol and tamoxifen.
  • If the woman is experiencing cyclical breast pain in addition to other physical and psychological premenstrual symptoms, see the CKS topic on Premenstrual syndrome for more information.
  • Do not routinely recommend the following treatments for cyclical breast pain:
    • Stopping or changing other medication, including combined oral contraceptives.
    • Evening primrose oil.
    • Progestogen-only contraceptives.
    • Diets low in fat or low in caffeine.
    • Antibiotics.
    • Diuretics.
    • Pyridoxine.
    • Tibolone.
    • Vitamin E.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Reassurance
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article which suggests that as long as malignancy has been excluded as a cause, usually cyclical breast pain can be managed by watchful waiting without treatment [Amin et al, 2013]. Expert opinion in a textbook: ABC of breast diseases describes reassurance as the 'mainstay of treatment' for mastalgia [Iddon and Dixon, 2012].
Wearing a well-fitting bra 
  • The advice to wear a well-fitting bra is based on expert opinion in a US guideline [University of Michigan Health System, 2013] and review articles [Salzman et al, 2012; Amin et al, 2013]. The recommendation to consider wearing a soft support bra at night is based on expert opinion in a textbook with the rationale that it supports tender breast tissues and reduces tension on the chest wall [Iddon and Dixon, 2012].
Simple oral analgesia as first-line treatment 
  • The recommendation to offer simple oral analgesia as first-line treatment is based on expert opinion in a US guideline [University of Michigan Health System, 2013] and review articles [Salzman et al, 2012; Amin et al, 2013].
  • A systematic review (search date February 2014) found no good quality evidence comparing the effectiveness of oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) with placebo for cyclical breast pain [Goyal, 2014]. CKS identified no trials of the use of paracetamol for cyclical breast pain.
Topical NSAIDs as first-line treatment
  • A systematic review (search date February 2014) [Goyal, 2014] found evidence from:
    • One small randomized controlled trial (RCT — n = 60) that topical diclofenac may be more effective than placebo in reducing breast pain. Irregular usage and abruptly stopping treatment created no serious problems. 
    • Another randomized controlled trial (n = 100) of a non-significant effect when topical and oral diclofenac were compared for the treatment of cyclical and non-cyclical breast pain.
  • Expert opinion suggests that topical NSAIDs are effective in relieving breast pain and that the benefits outweigh the risk of adverse effects if long-term treatment is avoided [Salzman et al, 2012; University of Michigan Health System, 2013; Goyal, 2014]. 
Pain chart
  • This recommendation is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Managing premenstrual syndrome
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and based on expert opinion in a textbook that different treatments may be considered if cyclical breast pain is part of a premenstrual syndrome [Iddon and Dixon, 2012].
Referral
  • The recommendation to refer if cyclical breast pain is affecting quality of life or sleep is based on expert opinion in a review article [Dixon and Thomas, 2012]. The timescale of 3 months is based on observational trial evidence in a US guideline on common breast problems [University of Michigan Health System, 2013].
    • A systematic review (search date: February 2014) found evidence from randomized controlled trials to suggest that danazol, tamoxifen, and gonadorelin analogues reduce cyclical breast pain compared with placebo [Goyal, 2014]. Expert opinion in a textbook also discusses the use of tamoxifen and danazol [Iddon and Dixon, 2012].
    • However, these treatments can cause unpleasant and serious adverse effects [Iddon and Dixon, 2012; Goyal, 2014]. CKS therefore advises that their use is limited to specialists or those with a specialist interest in the management of breast pain.
Treatments not recommended
Changing or stopping medication
  • Changing current medication to treat breast pain is not advised as there is little evidence to suggest a link between any drug treatment and the onset of cyclical breast pain. There is no evidence to suggest that the use of combined oral contraceptives causes cyclical breast pain. There is evidence from a randomized controlled trial  (n = 82) [Graham and Sherwin, 1992] and a cohort study (n = 552) [Bancroft and Rennie, 1993] that premenstrual breast pain may improve with oral contraceptive use.
Evening primrose oil
  • There is evidence from a systematic review of four RCTs to show that evening primrose oil is no more effective than placebo at reducing the frequency and severity of breast pain [Srivastava et al, 2007] and a lack of good quality evidence to support its use. For this reason, in 2002, the UK Medicines Control Agency withdrew the prescription licence from evening primrose oil to treat breast pain [Iddon and Dixon, 2012]. 
Progestogen-only contraceptives
  • There is weak evidence from a cross-sectional survey to suggest that parenteral medroxyprogesterone acetate reduces cyclical breast pain compared with control [Euhus and Uyehara, 1997], but it is insufficient to recommend this as a treatment. There is weak evidence that oral progestogen (oral medroxyprogesterone) is no better than placebo at treating breast pain [Maddox et al, 1990].
Diet changes
  • There is little good-quality evidence to suggest that a diet low in fat or caffeine is beneficial for the treatment of cyclical breast pain [Chase et al, 2011; Iddon and Dixon, 2012].
Antibiotics, diuretics, pyridoxine, or vitamin E
  • There is a lack of evidence to suggest a benefit from the use of antibiotics, diuretics, pyridoxine, or vitamin E. Even though there is a placebo effect from these agents, they have potential adverse effects and therefore should not be used for the treatment of breast pain.
